Award.AwardTitle: Novel Approaches to Nonlinear Panel Data Analysis and Model Selection

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will devise methods to handle the uncertainty that often is encountered in economic and statistical modeling. The project considers uncertainty taking the form of (i) unobserved variables and (ii) imperfect knowledge of the model itself. The first part of the project focuses on nonlinear panel data models, which currently are receiving considerable attention in economic and statistical modeling because they provide a natural way to describe the heterogeneity present in a population. These models share the feature of including various unobserved variables that represent factors that are constant over time but vary over individuals. The project will combine the ideas of entropy maximization and simulation-based estimation to handle, in a unified framework, the unobservable variables present in a wide range of nonlinear panel data models. The approach used aims to bypass the complex task of establishing identification of the model without sacrificing explanatory power. The second part of this project proposes a new, simple, approach to model selection that relies on method of moments estimation, adapted to deliver tests that are identically distributed whether or not the candidates models are overlapping. Model selection historically has received a lot of attention, but often involves the cumbersome step of "pre-testing" to first decide if the candidate models are overlapping or not. The key to avoiding pre-testing is to smoothly interpolate (rather than discontinuously switch) between a method valid for overlapping models and a method valid for non overlapping models.

Given the large number of researchers focusing on nonlinear panel data models and model selection, any new development within these fields is likely to be of interest to a large community in virtually all fields of the social, medical, mathematical, and natural sciences. Ultimately, this project will enable more accurate statistical inference in these fields and permit the practical use of more general statistical models. Computer programs implementing the methods will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in the development of a new method computational statistical method (called Entropic Latent Variable Integration via Simulation, or ELVIS), which provides a simple and very general way to incorporate latent (or unobserved) variables within the widely used Generalized Method of Moment (GMM) framework that underlies much of statistical analysis of economic data. The approach avoids the tedious process of analytically solving for the possible distributions of the unobserved variables and instead replaces it by a computer-intensive but automatic simulation-based numerical method. The method has been demonstrated to handle a wide range of settings commonly found in economic data, such as: (i) censored or truncated variables (ii) measurement error (iii) interval data (as opposed to data points), (iv) models arising in the field of game-theory and (v) dynamic models with unobserved state variables (widely used to study economic time series).

The project has also significantly advanced our ability to properly handle statistical data contaminated with measurement error. A long-standing problem was solved: It was demonstrated that the classical linear regression with errors in both the dependent and independent variables can be generalized to nonlinear relationships even when no additional information regarding the form of measurement error is available (such as its distribution). New methods were also proposed to handle nonclassical forms of measurement errors, such as models where the error is not additive or where the noise is correlated with the signal.

Finally, a new method to select the best model to describe given statistical data was developed. This method considerably simplifies the model selection process by providing, for the first time, a statistical test that always has the same asymptotic normal distribution whether the models are overlapping, nested  or non-nested.

The project has already led to publications in three leading journals in their respective fields: the Journal of the American Statistical Association the Annals of Statistics, and Econometrica. During the course of this project, the PI was awarded (jointly with F. Cunha and J. Heckman) the Frisch Medal of the Econometric Society for a paper that employs the PI's statistical methods to the analysis of the cognitive and noncognitive skill development in childhood.
